title: Alexander Executive Search Redefines Hiring: Why Behavioral Fit Should Outweigh Skills in Building Lasting Teams
description: Rather than sending resumes alone, Alexander Executive Search provides a comprehensive candidate briefing pack.
content:
Hiring and retaining the right talent is one of today’s most persistent corporate challenges. All too often, organizations default to evaluating objective factors, skills, qualifications, and experience, while giving little importance to the nuances of behavior, motivation, and cultural fit. As Keith Fox, founder of Alexander Executive Search, points out, “People are hired on skills and experience and fired on behavior and performance.”

This misguided focus yields hiring decisions built on resumes rather than people, resulting in mismatches, disillusionment, and churn that weaken both team cohesion and brand reputation.

Traditional recruitment systems, in their emphasis on objective credentials, reduce people to checklists. A candidate may meet the technical job requirements, and a placement would be made, but there would be little assurance that the individual will flourish, much less stay.

“Companies need to be careful,” Fox notes, “because companies with high turnovers can develop negative reputations.” The real cost lies not only in replacing someone who didn’t fit, but in the morale and cultural toll on those left behind.

According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the median employee tenure in US industries hovers around 3.9 years, while voluntary quits remain persistently high. Additionally, turnover costs an estimated 33 percent of a worker’s annual salary to replace a mid-level employee. These figures underscore the importance and urgency of aligning hires with both the role and environment, rather than settling for surface-level factors, and that’s what Fox’s work represents.

Fox’s approach at Alexander Executive Search defines a new narrative in hiring, one that restores the focus on the person, not just the paper. Fox says, “We take measures to ensure employee retention, as well as offer a replacement within the 12-month period.”

This isn’t luck, it’s evidence that behavior matters more than skills. “Skills are a tick-box exercise,” he notes. “The thing that gets people to move jobs is behaviors. Someone can be the best in their role, but if the environment doesn’t suit their behaviors, they’ll dissipate into a role they’ll dislike.”

Alexander Executive Search’s methodology embeds behavioral alignment into every phase of the process. Upon partnering, clients gain access to a secure, web-enabled portal, accessible on any device, where they can oversee their assignments in real time. They see each candidate’s status, aligned to job descriptions and key expectations, in an interface designed for clarity and transparency.

Rather than sending resumes alone, Alexander Executive Search provides a comprehensive candidate briefing pack. Not only encapsulating job specifications, but also a curated introduction to the hiring company’s philosophies, operations, products, and values. It outlines the process, the retention guarantees, and what’s expected from both sides.

What elevates this further is the use of a behavior-focused job survey. Hiring managers complete a multiple-choice tick-box assessment that outlines the behavioral profile required. These profiles are then compared across candidates, producing strategic insights.

Each candidate’s journey is transparent; users can see completion of each hiring stage, including behavioral assessment, submission of a short introduction video, photo upload, resume, and responses to key competency questions. The system even integrates with behavioral assessments, offering behavioral analysis, stress response insights, tailored interview questions, and precise guidance on how to manage the candidate.

Beyond assessment, the portal supports interview scheduling across time zones, collective rating from the hiring team, and side-by-side comparison of how each candidate was received.

Fox emphasizes the holistic human element in recruitment. His “head, heart, and mind” approach ensures candidates are engaged intellectually, emotionally, and ethically. “I don’t pitch someone solely on earning more,” he says. Instead, he seeks alignment between what makes the candidate happy and how they’ll contribute meaningfully.

Alexander Executive Search’s sourcing is direct and old-school. Fox doesn’t believe in formal, rudimentary emails and phone calls, and instead enforces an in-person approach. “I’m quite old school,” Fox shares. “I tend to phone them, asking to meet over breakfast.” That personal touch, combined with the behavioral architecture of the portal and process, represents a recruitment system that acknowledges that the real challenge isn’t filling positions, it’s placing people.

Through headhunting and referencing largely in the civil engineering and construction landscape, the firm has recruited for companies globally, including in the US and Asia.

In a recruitment ecosystem struggling with low engagement and high turnover, Alexander Executive Search offers a compelling alternative that merges behavioral science with transparent, collaborative processes. By putting human alignment at the heart of hiring, Fox reinstates that the difference between a costly hire and a successful one lies not in experience, but in character.
summary: Alexander Executive Search founder Keith Fox has developed a new approach to hiring and retaining talent, focusing on behavior, motivation, and cultural fit rather than the objective factors. This shift in hiring results in mismatches, disillusionment, and churning that weakens team cohesion and brand reputation. The company's focus is on behavior rather than skills, with Fox stating that high turnover rates can lead to negative reputations for companies with high employee morale and employee retention. His approach includes a comprehensive candidate briefing pack, a behavior-focused job survey, and transparent portal for the hiring process. Each candidate's journey is completed through behavioral assessment, including behavioral analysis, stress response insights, and tailored interview questions.
shortSummary: Alexander Executive Search emphasizes the importance of holistic hiring, focusing on behavior and integration rather than just technical skills, addressing high turnover and team cohesion.

Dive Brief:
- Employee Benefit News (EBN) reports that it costs employers 33% of a worker's annual salary to hire a replacement if that worker leaves. In dollar figures, the replacement cost is $15,000 per person for an employee earning a median salary of $45,000 a year, according to the Work Institute’s 2017 Retention Report. The study of 34,000 respondents concluded that 75% of the causes of employee turnover are preventable.
- The study also highlighted turnover's indirect costs, or “productivity costs,” says EBN. Indirect costs stem from knowledge lost when employees leave, the time spent finding a replacement and the time new hires need to become fully functional.
- In exit interviews, the top reasons survey respondents gave for leaving their jobs were career development (22%), work-life balance (12%), managers' behavior (11%), compensation and benefits (9%) and well-being (9%).
Dive Insight:
A separate Willis Tower Watson survey revealed that one in three hires will leave a job within two years, pressuring employers to find replacements quickly and absorb the high costs involved. This report reaches an interesting conclusion: employers might want to focus on shaping the workplace to fit the best hires instead of selecting people that fit the workplace.
Career development is a common reason for dissatisfaction on the job. More employers of all types are turning to employee learning programs to both keep people on the job and improve the quality of their workforce. Job responsibilities that don't meet expectations are another catalyst for turnover. Departing employees most likely had an unrealistic view of the job during the recruitment process, which can be partly solved by improving the language of job listings.
To maximize retention, employers need formal, consistent exit interviews. Finding out why people leave is key to finding ways to encourage top performers to stay. Employers also can develop talent pipelines by allowing employees to create networks and make referrals, which narrows the recruiting and hiring time needed to find replacements when workers do leave.

Supporting data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the Work Institute, and Willis Tower Watson shows that turnover costs up to 33% of a worker’s salary and that most departures are preventable, often due to misaligned expectations, management behavior, and lack of career development.
